Dear John, others - 

I've posted a photo of the interesting namban tsuba t=
hat John had referred to earlier. The motif consists of dragons and catfish=
, a shrine (with gold jewel peak), breaking waves and vines (?) in sukashi =
work. This large tsuba (84mm rnd. x 4mm thick) has Tokubetsu Hozon certific=
ate. The poster is in Yahoo photos: http://tinyurl.com/yxt45h
in a file nam=
ed: Ron STL  Perhaps John wishes to elaborate on this tsuba a bit more? 

J=
ohn, I've just received my copy of your book, "The Namban Group of Japanese=
 Sword Guards; Aa Reappraisal" and I'm looking forward to digesting your re=
search findings which make up this publication. Interesting!

Ron
STL

  --=
--- Original Message ----- 
  From: Dr John P Lissenden 
  To: nihontostudy=
@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Wednesday, December 06, 2006 7:37 AM
  Subject: [=
nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba help


  Dear Patrick

  Yes indeed - one of the Na=
mban group and probably made by a casting 
  process in the early-mid C19. =
This group is characterised by its 
  openwork and undercutting; the common=
 presence of affronted dragons 
  with the tama jewel; and the atypically s=
haped seppa-dai. All of 
  these are present on your tsuba.

  I would have=
 expected a tsuba of this type to be of iron, but some 
  were cast in bron=
ze. Interestingly these are unexpectedly attracted 
  by a magnet, but the =
admixture of up to 30% of iron to bronze in 
  order to reduce the cost of =
the expensive alloy was not unknown. 
  Also, iron was a common inclusion i=
n naturally occurring copper ore 

  Regards, John L.
